Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Operative vs. Nonoperative Treatment for Lumbar Disc Herniations

Trial_Design.evidence: randomised controlled trial included patients with lumbar disc herniations

Participants.evidence: patients with lumbar disc herniations at L2-L3, L3-L4, L4-L5, or L5-S1

Intervention.evidence: operative versus nonoperative treatment for lumbar disc herniations

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to assess the impact of herniation level on the outcomes of operative versus nonoperative treatment for lumbar disc herniations.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcomes were the Short Form-36 bodily pain and physical functioning scales and the modified Oswestry Disability Index, measured at six weeks, three months, six months, one year, and two years.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was achieved using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment maintained.

Blinding.evidence: Due to the nature of the interventions, blinding was not feasible.

Number_Randomised.evidence: The study analysed 646 L5-S1, 456 L4-L5, and 88 upper lumbar herniations.

Number_Analysed.evidence: The study analysed 646 L5-S1, 456 L4-L5, and 88 upper lumbar herniations.

Result_Outcome.evidence: 24.6 vs. 7.1 for bodily pain (p = 0.002); 23.4 vs. 9.9 for physical functioning (p = 0.014); and −19 vs. −10.3 for Oswestry Disability Index (p = 0.033).
